title: About Emmett Stralka
text:
My Journey



üéì


Academic Foundation
I‚Äôm currently pursuing a dual major in Engineering and Economics at Harvey Mudd College, one of the nation‚Äôs premier institutions for science and engineering education. This unique combination allows me to approach technical challenges with both engineering rigor and business acumen.
My coursework spans across multiple disciplines including:

Microcontrollers and FPGA Design (E155)
Digital Electronics and Circuit Design
Product Management and UX/UI Design
Economic Analysis and Market Strategy





üíº


Professional Experience
I‚Äôve had the privilege of gaining hands-on experience through internships at leading companies:

Ford Motor Company
Worked on automotive engineering projects, gaining insight into large-scale manufacturing and product development processes.


Abercrombie & Fitch
Contributed to business strategy and market analysis, understanding the intersection of technology and consumer behavior.


North American Switchgear
Applied technical engineering skills in electrical systems and power distribution, working on critical infrastructure projects.
These diverse experiences have given me a unique perspective on how technical innovation drives business success across different industries.





üöÄ


Technical Projects & Interests
I‚Äôm actively involved in several exciting technical domains:

Advanced Rocketry
Working on high-performance rocket systems, focusing on propulsion, guidance, and recovery systems. This combines mechanical engineering, electronics, and systems integration.


Robotics & Automation
Developing autonomous systems and robotic solutions for various applications, from industrial automation to research platforms.


Signal Processing
Exploring digital signal processing techniques for communication systems, sensor data analysis, and real-time processing applications.
These projects allow me to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world challenges while developing practical engineering skills.





üèÉ


Athletic Excellence
Beyond academics and engineering, I‚Äôm a varsity track and field athlete and SCIAC champion. This experience has taught me invaluable lessons about:

Discipline: The importance of consistent practice and continuous improvement
Teamwork: Working collaboratively toward common goals
Resilience: Overcoming setbacks and pushing beyond perceived limits
Time Management: Balancing rigorous training with academic excellence

These qualities directly translate to my engineering work, where persistence, collaboration, and attention to detail are essential for success.

title: About Emmett Stralka
text:
E155: Microcontrollers & FPGA Design



‚ö°


Course Overview
This website documents my comprehensive journey through E155: Microcontrollers and FPGA Design at Harvey Mudd College. This course represents a deep dive into embedded systems, digital design, and hardware-software integration.
Throughout this course, I‚Äôm developing expertise in:

FPGA programming and digital circuit design
Microcontroller architecture and peripheral programming
Assembly language and low-level programming
Real-time systems and interrupt-driven programming
Hardware debugging and testing methodologies

Each lab builds upon previous knowledge, creating a comprehensive understanding of modern embedded systems design.

title: About Emmett Stralka
text:
My Approach to Engineering



üéØ


Problem-Solving Philosophy
I believe in a systematic approach to engineering challenges:

1. Understanding the Problem
Thoroughly analyzing requirements, constraints, and stakeholder needs before jumping to solutions.


2. Research & Analysis
Investigating existing solutions, best practices, and emerging technologies that could inform the design.


3. Iterative Design
Building prototypes, testing assumptions, and refining solutions based on real-world feedback.


4. Documentation & Communication
Clearly documenting decisions, processes, and outcomes to enable knowledge sharing and future improvements.

title: E155 Labs
text:
Microcontrollers & FPGA Design
Documentation of my journey through E155: Microcontrollers and FPGA Design at Harvey Mudd College, mastering embedded systems, digital design, and hardware-software integration.

Progress: 2/7 labs completed (29%) | Current: Interrupts and Timers | Next: Memory-Mapped I/O

title: E155 Labs
text:
Lab Portfolio



‚úì Completed


Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup
Initial setup and configuration of the development environment, including FPGA programming and microcontroller initialization.

Deep dive into low-level programming with assembly language, implementing core algorithms and data manipulation techniques directly on the microcontroller.

Exploring real-time programming concepts through interrupt-driven systems and timer-based operations.

Implementation of memory-mapped input/output operations, enabling direct hardware control through memory addressing.

Working with ADC peripherals to interface with analog sensors and signals, covering signal conditioning and sampling theory.

title: Star Wars Episode III Reflection
text:
Summary
Star Wars: Episode III ‚Äì Revenge of the Sith is the culmination of the prequel trilogy, showing Anakin Skywalker‚Äôs tragic fall to the dark side and the rise of the Empire. The film covers critical events like the Clone Wars ending, Order 66, and Anakin becoming Darth Vader. Visually, it features stunning space battles, lightsaber duels, and iconic planets such as Mustafar and Coruscant.

title: Star Wars Episode III Reflection
text:
Reflection
Watching Episode III again, I was struck by how much the film balances political intrigue with personal tragedy. Anakin‚Äôs internal conflict is central, and Hayden Christensen‚Äôs portrayal really conveys the tension between his loyalty, fear, and ambition. I also appreciated how the film connects the prequels to the original trilogy, giving context to Darth Vader‚Äôs character and the Empire‚Äôs rise.
